summary: This document consists of three government status update letters to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's conditions of confinement at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in Brooklyn. The letters detail her access to discovery, attorney communication, COVID-19 protocols, quarantine procedures, daily routines, and searches, and respond to defense complaints about her treatment.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case, held at the Metropolitan Detention Center. The letters detail her conditions of confinement, including quarantine due to COVID-19 exposure, access to discovery materials, and communication with her attorneys.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The government letters are addressed to her, providing updates on the defendant's jail conditions pursuant to her court orders.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.role: Acting United States Attorney / United States Attorney
persons.context: The government attorney who submits the status update letters to the court on behalf of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.

connections.description: Strauss, as the Acting U.S. Attorney, is the lead prosecutor representing the government in the criminal case against defendant Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judicial officer over Maxwell's criminal case, issuing orders regarding her confinement and receiving updates from the government.

events.title: Maxwell Placed in Quarantine and Tested for COVID-19
events.description: After a staff member in her MDC housing area tested positive for COVID-19, Ghislaine Maxwell was given a rapid test (which was negative) and placed in a 14-day quarantine in her existing cell.

events.title: Suspension of In-Person Visits at MDC
events.description: Due to an elevated number of COVID-19 cases within the Metropolitan Detention Center, in-person visits for all inmates, including attorney visits for Maxwell, were suspended.

events.title: MDC Resumes In-Person Visitation
events.description: The Metropolitan Detention Center resumed in-person attorney visits, making them available seven days a week. The government notes Maxwell's defense counsel declined in-person meetings, opting for video calls instead.

events.title: Maxwell Fully Vaccinated Against COVID-19
events.description: The government reports that Ghislaine Maxwell has received the COVID-19 vaccine and is now fully vaccinated.

keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was granted extensive and privileged access to review discovery, receiving 13 hours per day, 7 days a week on both a government-provided laptop and an MDC desktop computer, which was stated to be more than any other inmate at the MDC.

Maxwell's conditions included rigorous search protocols: daily pat-downs (including mouth checks), weekly body scans, daily cell searches, and 15-minute nighttime wellness checks where staff used a flashlight to confirm she was breathing.

The government defended the MDC's handling of Maxwell's complaints, including an investigation that found a pat-down search she complained about was appropriately conducted and recorded, and that issues with her cell cleanliness were due to her own hygiene habits.
Maxwell's weight was monitored, fluctuating between the 130s and 140s, with her lowest recorded weight being 133 pounds in July 2021, which corresponded to a normal BMI for her height (5'7").

Attorney communication shifted from in-person visits to daily video-teleconference (VTC) calls during COVID-19 suspensions, with Maxwell eventually receiving up to 5 hours of VTC calls with counsel on weekdays.
